title: Tcl module files should let `man` fall back on system man pages

labels.name: triage
labels.description: The issue needs to be prioritized

body:
When a generated tcl module file modifies `MANPATH`, the system man pages are completely unavailable.  This is the expected `man` behavior when `MANPATH` is set, but it's unintuitive and frustrating if you're unfamiliar with how man pages are found.


### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ printenv MANPATH

$ man -w ls 
/usr/share/man/man1/ls.1.gz
$ spack load gcc
$ printenv MANPATH
/home/dringo/spack/opt/spack/linux-antergos19-x86_64/gcc-8.3.0/gcc-8.2.0-qxn3zuh54mofm3a5xglxmghvwqvoujq6/share/man
$ man -w gcc 
/home/dringo/spack/opt/spack/linux-antergos19-x86_64/gcc-8.3.0/gcc-8.2.0-qxn3zuh54mofm3a5xglxmghvwqvoujq6/share/man/man1/gcc.1
$ man -w ls
No manual entry for ls
```

### Potential solutions/workarounds

On most systems, adding a trailing colon to the `MANPATH` will cause system directories to be searched after those in `MANPATH` (similarly, a leading colon gives precedence to system dirs).  I'm not sure which systems this is _not_ true for -- I'm just parroting what I've read around the web.  This means you could always run `man` as `MANPATH="$MANPATH:" man <command>` or export an appropriately modified `MANPATH` every time you load a spack module file, but that's a point of unnecessary friction in my opinion.

A better, but still ugly solution would be to modify tcl module file template to always suffix a colon to `MANPATH` in module files that otherwise modify it.  I think the following will guarantee that the colon is always at the end, but I don't know much about Tcl or module files.  Maybe there's something cleaner?

```
remove-path MANPATH ""
append-path MANPATH ""
```

### Information on your system

I'm using spack on `develop` at `5b82bf47af` and `environment-modules@4.2.3%gcc@8.2.0 ~X` installed by `spack bootstrap`.

I don't think the rest is super relevant, but I'm including it for completeness:

`uname -a` reports
`Linux slartibartfast 5.0.10-arch1-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Apr 27 20:06:45 UTC 2019 x86_64 unknown unknown GNU/Linux`

The only non-default spack configuration I have is to use `gcc@8.2.0` installed by spack as the default compiler (built with my system gcc 8.3.0).
